ground_truth: In Scaled Dot-Product Attention, the weights assigned to each value are computed using a compatibility function of the query with the corresponding key. This is done by computing the dot products of the query with all keys, dividing each by the square root of the dimension of the keys (dk), and then applying a softmax function. When multiple queries are processed simultaneously, they are packed together into a matrix Q, with the keys and values also packed into matrices K and V respectively. ground_truth:
The path length between long-range dependencies in a network significantly impacts the ability to learn such dependencies. The shorter the paths between any combination of positions in the input and output sequences, the easier it is to learn long-range dependencies. This is because shorter paths allow for quicker and more efficient propagation of signals in both forward and backward directions during the learning process. 

When comparing the maximum path length between any two input and output positions in networks composed of different layer types, a self-attention layer has an advantage. It connects all positions with a constant number of sequentially executed operations, allowing for shorter path lengths and thus easier learning of long-range dependencies. On the other hand, a recurrent layer requires O(n) sequential operations, which can result in longer path lengths and potentially make learning long-range dependencies more challenging. 

Therefore, the type of layer used in a network can significantly affect the maximum path length and consequently the ability to learn long-range dependencies. This is an important consideration when designing networks for tasks that require understanding of long-range dependencies.

Training
This section describes the training regime for our models.
5.1
Training Data and Batching
We trained on the standard WMT 2014 English-German dataset consisting of about 4.5 million
sentence pairs. Sentences were encoded using byte-pair encoding [3], which has a shared source-
target vocabulary of about 37000 tokens. For English-French, we used the significantly larger WMT
2014 English-French dataset consisting of 36M sentences and split tokens into a 32000 word-piece
vocabulary [38]. Sentence pairs were batched together by approximate sequence length. Each training
batch contained a set of sentence pairs containing approximately 25000 source tokens and 25000
target tokens.

We apply dropout [33] to the output of each sub-layer, before it is added to the
sub-layer input and normalized. In addition, we apply dropout to the sums of the embeddings and the

Pdrop = 0.1.
Label Smoothing
During training, we employed label smoothing of value ϵls = 0.1 [36]. This
hurts perplexity, as the model learns to be more unsure, but improves accuracy and BLEU score.

Conclusion
In this work, we presented the Transformer, the first sequence transduction model based entirely on
attention, replacing the recurrent layers most commonly used in encoder-decoder architectures with
multi-headed self-attention.
For translation tasks, the Transformer can be trained significantly faster than architectures based
on recurrent or convolutional layers. On both WMT 2014 English-to-German and WMT 2014
English-to-French translation tasks, we achieve a new state of the art. In the former task our best
model outperforms even all previously reported ensembles.
We are excited about the future of attention-based models and plan to apply them to other tasks. We
plan to extend the Transformer to problems involving input and output modalities other than text and
to investigate local, restricted attention mechanisms to efficiently handle large inputs and outputs
ground_truth: The Transformer model offers several advantages over architectures based on recurrent or convolutional layers for translation tasks. Firstly, it can be trained significantly faster. Secondly, it has achieved a new state of the art on both WMT 2014 English-to-German and WMT 2014 English-to-French translation tasks, outperforming even all previously reported ensembles. The Transformer model is also versatile and can be extended to problems involving input and output modalities other than text.
